channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Jan Henning Thorsen and Marcus Ramberg about Convos, the web-based IRC client
item.description: Conos is built on Mojolicious. You can easily set up an in-hous web-based chat system, without people even knowing they use the in-house IRC behind.

item.title: TDD: The Bad Parts
item.description: A 30-minute talk on some problems you might hit with test-driven design.

item.title: 5 reasons to finally learn design patterns
item.description: Eric Freeman and Elisabeth Robson talk through 5 benefits of learning design patterns.

item.title: I'm learning Rust!
item.description: To help with learning Rust, Rik is implementing the examples from the classic Software Tools book in Rust.

item.title: Tony Cook's Grant Report
item.description: An update on work done by Tony under his grant for maintaining Perl 5.

item.title: Improve your chances of survival at Job Interviews and Public Speaking
item.description: Some tips on how to prepare yourself for speaking.

item.title: Deciding what to talk about
item.description: The second of a series of posts, that aim to encourage people who've never given a talk to submit a proposal.

item.title: Test for expected warnings
item.description: Gabor shows how you can use Test::Warn to test your module for warnings you expect it to emit in certain situations.

item.title: Release candidate for Rakudo Star 2016.10
item.description: If you use Rakudo Star, they'd appreciate any testing and feedback.

item.title: Hangman
item.description: Ken has been learning Haskell, and having written the Hangman game in Haskell, he then had a go at doing the same thing in Perl 6.

item.title: Perl6::Parser available for Perl 6
item.description: Jeff's first release of a Perl 6 module for parsing Perl 6. As Jeff says, this might be handy for pretty printers, syntax highlighting, etc.

item.title: Linux Clocks
item.description: Frew shows how he improved the logging of CPU usage at ZipRecruiter.

item.title: Dokku - Your Tiny PaaS
item.description: Flavio introduces Dokku, a tiny platform-as-a-service, which aims to make it easy to deploy a single service on a machine. The example he presents is a simple Mojolicious app.

item.title: Adventure with PVS C analyzer
item.description: Dmitry tried PVS Studio, a static code analyser for C and friends, to check some of his C/XS code. He was pleasantly surprised, but your wallet might balk at the price.

item.title: Perl 5 Porters Mailing List Summary: September 29th - October 10th
item.description: A relatively quiet week on P5P, given this summary.

item.title: New release of Statocles blog engine
item.description: Doug's released a new version of his static blogging engine, Statocles. If you're thinking of starting a blog, maybe take a look at this.

item.title: Dancer2 0.204000
item.description: A new table release of Dancer, the main features of which are improved configuration handling, and improved static content caching.

item.title: MooX::LvalueAttribute - improved
item.description: Damien has released a new version of his MooX::LvalueAttribute module, which lets you have lvalue accessors.

item.title: Next stable DBD::SQLite will be released in mid November
item.description: Ishigaki-san is planning the next stable release of DBD::SQLite in November. If you use SQLite and Perl, he'd appreciate you testing your code ahead of then.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description: Miguel Prz (NICEPERL)'s regular lists: Great modules released last week; MetaCPAN weekly report; StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: What's new on CPAN - September 2016
item.description: David's monthly round-up of new modules released on CPAN in the previous month.

item.title: #273 - Release candidates needing testing
item.description:
Once something has a lot of users, you need to be a lot more careful about your releases. One key tool is the release candidate: you put out a developer release and ask friendly developers to test it and let you know if there are any problems. No matter how thorough and diligent your testing, people and their data have a habit of doing things you never imagined.

So read on about people who need your help with testing their release candidates!

More Perl news
item.dc:subject: list of tags?
